description.narrative: In Sub-Saharan Africa various regional, sub-regional, and national organizations have been established to respond to the emerging crises on the continent. In addition to the African Union (AU), at the sub-regional level, the Regional Economic Communities ( RECs), such as ECOWAS, SADC, ECCAS and IGAD, have become integral building blocks of the African Peace and Security Architecture (APSA). While the AU maintains overall responsibility for peace and security issues on the continent, the RECs ? being geograph ically close to and often more affected by civil and regionalized conflicts ? are considered principal conflict resolution actors in their respective sub-regions. Within the APSA, the Principle of Subsidiarity serves as the guiding principle for organizing coordination and collaboration between the AU and the RECs. Although relatively robust, these mechanisms for conflict prevention and peace mediation are young and, as such, lack sufficient capacities to effectively and efficiently respond to the diverse p eace and security challenges on the continent. Moreover, the lack of collaboration between regional, sub-regional, and national actors and insufficient inclusivity of peace processes remains a particularly significant challenge to reaching sustainable solu tions to emerging crises in Africa through peace mediation. The problem addressed by this project is the limited conflict prevention and mediation capacities of African national, regional and sub-regional actors. CMI is well positioned to support and build the capacities of African regional, sub-regional, and national actors for various reasons. Above all, CMI maintains partnerships with key actors in Sub-Saharan Africa, including the AU and a number of RECs (ECOWAS, ECCAS) along with influential non-state actors, such as the West Africa Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP) and the African Centre for the Constructive Resolution of Disputes (ACCORD). In contributing to the strengthening of African conflict prevention and mediation capacities and enhancing the qu ality of peace processes, the African Mediation Capacities project focuses on two component areas: operational support and policy work.
